title: Maryland football is running more plays than any Big Ten team this season
text:
After leading the Big Ten conference in offensive plays by the end of last season, Penn State football has fallen behind this season.
The Terps have taken their spot, already showing they are running more plays this season.
Here is how we compared the Big Ten teams’ offense.
First, we loaded the necessary libraries and the football data from the 2023 season and the 2024 season thus far.


Code
library(tidyverse)


Warning: package 'tidyverse' was built under R version 4.3.3


Warning: package 'ggplot2' was built under R version 4.3.3


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
library(scales)



Attaching package: 'scales'

The following object is masked from 'package:purrr':

    discard

The following object is masked from 'package:readr':

    col_factor


Code
football23 <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs23.csv")


Rows: 1702 Columns: 54
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (8): HomeAway, Opponent, Result, TeamFull, TeamURL, Outcome, Team, Con...
dbl  (45): Game, PassingCmp, PassingAtt, PassingPct, PassingYds, PassingTD, ...
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Code
football24 <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs24.csv")


Rows: 704 Columns: 54
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (8): HomeAway, Opponent, Result, TeamFull, TeamURL, Outcome, Team, Con...
dbl  (45): Game, PassingCmp, PassingAtt, PassingPct, PassingYds, PassingTD, ...
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Then, we found the average number of offensive plays per game for the Big Ten teams in 2023.


Code
averages23 <- football23 |>
  filter(Conference == 'Big Ten Conference') |>
  group_by(TeamFull) |>
  summarise(
    average_offense = mean(OffensivePlays)
  ) |>
  arrange(desc(average_offense))


And this season.


Code
averages24 <- football24 |>
  filter(Conference == 'Big Ten Conference') |>
  group_by(TeamFull) |>
  summarise(
    average_offense = mean(OffensivePlays)
  ) |>
  arrange(desc(average_offense))


We then created bar charts to see how teams compared to each other in offensive plays. We found that in 2023, Penn State finished on top with an average over 70 and Iowa at the bottom just under 60.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(
    data=averages23, 
    aes(
      x=reorder(TeamFull, `average_offense`), 
      weight=`average_offense`
      )
    ) + 
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
    title="Penn State football led the Big Ten in offensive plays in 2023", 
    x="School", 
    y="Average Offensive Plays"
)









So far this season, Maryland has led the conference with an average over 70 and Purdue a little over 50.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(
    data=averages24, 
    aes(
      x=reorder(TeamFull, `average_offense`), 
      weight=`average_offense`
      )
    ) + 
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
    title="Terps football leads the Big Ten in offensive plays", 
    x="School", 
    y="Average Offensive Plays"
)









On average, teams have had about 60 to 70 offensive plays per game in 2023 and 2024. But this season, with more teams in the conference, a couple of them have fallen behind at about 55.
While Penn State led the conference last year, they are sitting at about average. Maryland, on the other hand, is already outperforming its last season with an average higher than any team in both seasons.

title: Maryland is playing better defensive volleyball
text:
Maryland women’s volleyball is gaining more points from defensive plays than their Big Ten peer Northwestern.
Here is how we figured that out.
First, we loaded the necessary libraries and the most current women’s volleyball data. Then, we found the total number of kills, blocks, aces and opponent errors for both teams and saved those in a value for each school.


Code
library(tidyverse)


Warning: package 'tidyverse' was built under R version 4.3.3


Warning: package 'ggplot2' was built under R version 4.3.3


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
volleyball <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dwillis/NCAAWomensVolleyballData/main/data/ncaa_womens_volleyball_matchstats_2024.csv")


Rows: 5235 Columns: 39
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (4): team, opponent, home_away, result
dbl  (34): ncaa_id, team_score, opponent_score, s, kills, errors, total_atta...
date  (1): date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.


Code
md_volleyball <- volleyball |>
  filter(team == "Maryland") |>
  summarise(
    total_kills = sum(kills),
    total_blocks = sum(block_solos) + sum(block_assists),
    total_aces = sum(aces),
    total_opperr = sum(defensive_errors) 
  )

md <- c("Kills"=714, "Blocks"=253, "Aces"=127,"OppErr"=323)

nw_volleyball <- volleyball |>
  filter(team == "Northwestern") |>
  summarise(
    total_kills = sum(kills),
    total_blocks = sum(block_solos) + sum(block_assists),
    total_aces = sum(aces),
    total_opperr = sum(defensive_errors) 
  )

nw <- c("Kills"=547, "Blocks"=207, "Aces"=61,"OppErr"=238, 364)


Finally, we created a waffle chart showing the distribution of those points for each school.


Code
library(waffle)


Warning: package 'waffle' was built under R version 4.3.3


Code
iron(
   waffle(md/4, 
        rows = 10, 
        title="Maryland Volleyball", 
        xlab="1 square = 1 point", 
        colors = c("black", "red", "blue", "green")
        ),
   waffle(nw/4, 
        rows = 10, 
        title="Northwestern Volleyball", 
        xlab="1 square = 1 point", 
        colors = c("black", "red", "blue", "green", "white")
        )
)









Overall, Maryland has more points from the combination of kills, blocks, aces and opponent errors than Northwestern. The greatest discrepancy between the two teams comes from Maryland’s kills. But Maryland beats them when comparing each of their points in those categories individually as well.
